# Add required imports
import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

# Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
# Database can be specified as a Spark Config or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
spark.conf.set("spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database", "SQLPoolTest")

# Read from a query
# Query can be provided either as an argument to synapsesql or as a Constant - Constants.QUERY
df = (spark.read
                     # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
                     # Database can be specified as a Spark Config - spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
                     .option(Constants.DATABASE, "SQLPoolTest")
                     # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
                     # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
                     .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
                     # Defaults to storage path defined in the runtime configurations
                     .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
                     # query from which data will be read
                     .option(Constants.QUERY, "select * from dbo.NATO_Tweets1")
                     .synapsesql()

# Select sample size for testing

# Sort ascending by 'created_at'
from pyspark.sql.functions import desc

df = df.orderBy(desc("created_at"))

from pyspark.sql.functions import regexp_replace

# Define the regular expression pattern to match words starting with @, &, or https
regex = r'@\w+|&\w+|https\w+|#\w+'

# Apply the regexp_replace function to the text column and create a new column with the filtered text
df = df.withColumn("text", regexp_replace(col("text"), regex, ''))

# Show the filtered DataFrame
df.select("text").show()

import synapse.ml
from synapse.ml.cognitive import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

# import required libraries
import json
from pyspark.sql.types import StructType, StructField, StringType
import pyspark.sql.functions as F

# Batch size
batch_size = 5

# First, count the total number of rows in the DataFrame
num_rows = df.count()

# Next, calculate the number of batches needed to split the DataFrame into batches of 5
num_batches = int(num_rows / batch_size) + (num_rows % batch_size > 0)

# Then, use randomSplit to split the DataFrame into smaller DataFrames of equal size
df_batches = df.randomSplit([1.0]*num_batches, seed=42)

# define the schema for the output DataFrame
schema = StructType([
    StructField("entity_text", StringType(), True),
    StructField("entity_category", StringType(), True)
    ])

# create an empty DataFrame with the defined schema
output_df = spark.createDataFrame([], schema)

# Finally, use limit to limit the number of rows in each DataFrame to 5
for i in range(num_batches):
    batch = df_batches[i].limit(batch_size)
    ner = (NER()
    .setLinkedService(linked_service_name)
    .setLanguageCol("lang")
    .setOutputCol("replies")
    .setErrorCol("error"))

    ner_batch_output = ner.transform(batch)
    #display(ner_batch_output)

    # Extract the 'replies' column and convert it to JSON
    json_output = ner_batch_output.select("replies").toJSON().collect()
    # Deserialize the JSON and extract the 'replies' field
    nes = [json.loads(x)["replies"] for x in json_output]

    # Print the 'replies' field for each row
    for each in nes:
        #print(each)

        # create a PySpark DataFrame from the JSON string
        json_string = each
        df = spark.read.json(sc.parallelize([json_string]))

        # extract the 'entities' array from the 'document' column
        df = df.selectExpr('explode(document.entities) as entities')

        # select the 'text' and 'category' fields from the exploded 'entities' array
        df = df.select('entities.text', 'entities.category')

        # rename the columns
        df = df.withColumnRenamed('text', 'entity_text')
        df = df.withColumnRenamed('category', 'entity_category')

        # show the resulting DataFrame
        #df.show()

        # Append the batch results dataframe to the main output dataframe
        output_df = output_df.union(df)
display(output_df)

# Write Spark Dataframe to Dedicated SQL Pool Table [NER].[NATO_NER]

from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants

# Configure and submit the request to write to Synapse Dedicated SQL Pool
# Sample below is using AAD-based authentication approach; See further examples to leverage SQL Basic auth.
(output_df.write
 # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
 # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
 .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
 # Like-wise, if `Constants.TEMP_FOLDER` is not provided, the connector will use the runtime staging directory config (see section on Configuration Options for details).
 .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")

 # refer to https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-data-sources-load-save-functions.html#save-modes
 .mode("overwrite")
 # Required parameter - Three-part table name to which data will be written
 .synapsesql("SQLPoolTest.NER.NATO_NER"))
